moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 d5:
This only drops a pawn. 4. Nf6 ... 5. d5 would have been good positional play. 4. exd5 Nb4 
5. Nc3, as shown in this game leaves you not only down in development but also down a pawn.
moves.4. exd5 Nb4 5. Nc3 c6: He is taking control of the center. d5 is starting to look more and more like a gambit than a pawn drop, if not a very effective one. d5xc6 is practically forced...
moves.6. dxc6 bxc6 7. Kf1: The mysterious king move. What was he looking at? What was he trying to achieve? Nobody knows but him.
moves.7... e4: Yay! Another pawn drop, an opponent's attacking Knight in great position, and complete loss of the center. It does make for an interesting development game, however.
moves.8. Nxe4 f5:
See what I mean? Interesting game.
9. d3 fxe4 
10. Bg5 Nf6 
11. Ne5 exd3 
12. Bf7+ Ke7 
13. Bxf6+ gxf6 
14. Nxc6+ 
Black doesn't necessarily drop his queen, not even close, but you get how d3 could be a scary positional gambit.
moves.9. d3:
9. d3 fxe4 
10. Bg5 Nf6 
11. Ne5 exd3 
12. Bf7+ Ke7 
13. Bxf6+ gxf6 
14. Nxc6+ 
Black doesn't neccesarily drop his queen, not even close, but you get how d3 could be a scary positional gambit.
